title: A Phase I, Randomised, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Parallel-group Single Ascending Dose Study to Assess the Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacokinetics, and Effect on Biomarkers of AZD3839 Including an Open-label Food Effect Group in Healthy Male and Female Volunteers of Non-childbearing Potential
description_brief: The purpose of the study is to assess the safety, tolerability and blood concentration of AZD3839 following oral administration of single doses in healthy men and women of non-childbearing potential
explanation_target: Reason: The investigational product AZD3839 is a small‑molecule inhibitor of BACE1 (β‑site APP‑cleaving enzyme 1), a key enzyme in production of amyloid‑β; the intended effect is lowering Aβ biomarkers (disease‑modifying mechanism), not symptomatic cognitive enhancement or psychiatric symptom management. citeturn0search2turn0search0

Act: Extracted details — Phase I single ascending dose, randomized double‑blind placebo‑controlled study in healthy volunteers, assessing safety, PK and effect on Aβ biomarkers; this matches a first‑in‑human SAD of a small‑molecule BACE1 inhibitor. citeturn0search0turn0search5
Evidence / web search results: discovery and preclinical characterization describing AZD3839 as a potent/selective BACE1 inhibitor that lowers Aβ in brain, CSF, and plasma. citeturn0search2
Evidence / clinical PK/PD: Phase I single‑ascending‑dose study reporting AZD3839 reduced plasma Aβ40/Aβ42 and reporting safety/PK (SAD design described in the trial you provided). citeturn0search0

Additional supporting sources (compound summaries/manufacturer listings) characterizing AZD3839 as a BACE1 inhibitor and noting Phase I development (development subsequently discontinued in later sources). citeturn0search4turn0search5

Reflect: Given AZD3839 is a small‑molecule BACE1 inhibitor targeting amyloid production (pathology), the correct category is 'disease-targeted small molecule'. It is not a biologic (e.g., antibody/vaccine), not described as a symptomatic cognitive enhancer, and not aimed at neuropsychiatric symptoms — therefore 'disease-targeted small molecule' is the best fit. citeturn0search2turn0search0
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational product AZD3839 is a small‑molecule inhibitor of BACE1 (β‑site APP‑cleaving enzyme 1), the enzyme that cleaves APP to produce amyloid‑β; the trial purpose (measuring effects on Aβ biomarkers) and the mechanism (blocking Aβ production) indicate an anti‑amyloid, disease‑modifying approach. citeturn1search4

Act: Extracted details from the description — Phase I single ascending dose, randomized double‑blind placebo‑controlled study in healthy volunteers testing AZD3839, an oral small‑molecule BACE1/β‑secretase inhibitor, with endpoints including effect on Aβ biomarkers (PK/PD, safety). These specifics match a first‑in‑human SAD of a BACE1 inhibitor whose intended biological target is amyloid‑β production. citeturn1search6turn0search5

Reflect: Classification check — CADRO category A) Amyloid beta covers interventions that target amyloid‑β production, aggregation, or clearance. Because AZD3839 directly inhibits BACE1 to reduce Aβ generation, the most specific CADRO assignment is A) Amyloid beta (not multi‑target or symptomatic). Development history (Phase I and subsequent discontinuation noted in some summaries) does not change the mechanistic classification. citeturn1search4turn0search4
